response.answer_text: As a distributor of eBooks, I can say with confidence that it can be quite profitable. It takes a lot of work, though. It doesn’t typically happen with the first book. Most authors fail to make money on their eBooks for any number of reasons. If you are self publishing your eBooks, you need to have the mindset of an entrepreneur. You will invest money up front to get a professional product to market (your book) and build an audience for that book. You will spend more money than you make in the beginning. Your first few hundred sales will be your most difficult. You will make mistakes. If you are dedicated, you will learn from these mistakes and get better at both the craft and business side of publishing. If you don’t want to do both, you’re doomed. Profitability in eBooks also depends a lot on the type of book you’re writing. Some genres are dominated by eBook sales. Other genres do better in print. Can you name 10 popular books in your genre (and subgenre)? If not, you need to do your research. I tell our authors to make a list of 10 popular books in their genre and study EVERYTHING about those books and authors — pricing, formats, titles, synopsis, marketing channels, metadata, genre, subgenres, categories, keywords. This is the type of market research entrepreneurial authors and publishers do all the time. It’s a great way to learn about the marketplace for your book, so you can position it correctly and get it in front of the right reviewers and readers. If you’re willing to write great books and commit to an entrepreneurial mindset, you’ve got a great chance. So the real question is: is selling eBooks going to be profitable for you? Only you can answer that question.
